title: https://elk.zone/

last_post.content:
Just wanted to share that I've been using https://elk.zone ( from @elk ) as a Mastodon web interface for a while now and I'm really happy with it.

So many things about it are better than the default #mastodon UI. Reading threads is notably nicer, and it supports multiple accounts, and it seems to get updates about notifications way sooner than the built-in UI ?!?!

Anyway. It's worth checking out.

title: A Number System Invented by Inuit Schoolchildren Will Make Its Silicon Valley Debut

last_post.content:
“30 years ago, a group of Inuit middle school students and their teacher invented the […] “Kaktovik numerals,” named after the Alaskan village where they were created, looked utterly different from decimal system numerals and functioned differently, too. But they were uniquely suited for quick, visual arithmetic using the traditional Inuit oral counting system, and they swiftly spread throughout the region.”
https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/a-number-system-invented-by-inuit-schoolchildren-will-make-its-silicon-valley-debut/

last_post.content:
Here is a must-read post from children's author Maggie Tokuda-Hall on how Scholastic offered to distribute her book — all she had to do was remove all mention of racism.

Sure, they're banning books in Tennessee and Texas. But it's not just the books that get published and then banned from the library. It's all the books that don't get published in the first place.

Those banning books know publishers like Scholastic pull this cowardly bullshit. It's their game plan.

title: copia.is/library/unintended-co...

last_post.content:

The paper is not an attack on the idea of regulating the internet, but rather calling out how terrible nearly every existing attempt has been, and how much damage each attempt has been towards both competition and speech:

title: Two algorithms for randomly generating aperiodic tilings

last_post.content: #monotile Reading this https://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/quasiblog/aperiodic-tilings/ on plotting monotiles, it talks about substitution rules making smaller and smaller tiles, but it seemed to me there should be a recurrence relation for plotting larger and larger monotiled patches from the H7/H8 rule. And there is, here's my code https://gist.github.com/bazzargh/961b6765042b17c0c25eadcc98b080e6 this also explains why H7/H8 tiles have 7/8 tiles at the base layer (one flipped) and 6/7 in later layers-the flipped tile is a hole!

title: Meet PassGAN, the supposedly “terrifying” AI password cracker that’s mostly hype

last_post.content:
By now, you’ve probably heard about a new AI-based password cracker that can compromise your password in seconds by using artificial intelligence instead of more traditional methods. Some outlets have called it "terrifying," "worrying," "alarming," and "savvy." Other publications have fallen over themselves to report that the tool can crack any password with up to seven characters—even if it has symbols and numbers—in under six minutes.

As with so many things involving AI, the claims are served with a generous portion of smoke and mirrors. PassGAN, as the tool is dubbed, performs no better than more conventional cracking methods. In short, anything PassGAN can do, these more tried and true tools do as well or better. And like so many of the non-AI password checkers Ars has criticized in the past the researchers behind PassGAN draw password advice from their experiment that undermines real security.

https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2023/04/the-passgan-ai-password-cracker-what-it-is-and-why-its-mostly-hype/

They are beta testing on civilians.

title: How Electrifying Everything Became a Key Climate Solution

last_post.content:
Total energy use in 🇺🇸.
And how much of it is currently electric.

Great illustration of the challenge, and opportunity, of electrification.

📰 https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2023/04/14/climate/electric-car-heater-everything.html

This well-written Open Access article by Shannon McGregor and @kreissdaniel critiques political polarization scholarship for overlooking the tension between progress toward social justice and social cohesion. With an important point that platforms cannot solve the underlying injustices that drive polarization. Platform's tech-solutionism for social cohesion thus ignores (and may risk undermining) struggles for progress. https://doi.org/10.1177/14614448231161880

title: Skirmish Society by Andy Wallace

last_post.content: Do you know Diplomacy, the board game for people who think they have too many friends? Skirmish Society is an asynchrone, Diplomacy-like game with a twist: it is a Discord bot. Every day, you just spend five minutes to tell the bot your orders, and four other hours to convince your neighbours to not invade your territories. title: raw.githubusercontent.com/make...

last_post.content:
Tone generation with #Python turns out to be relatively simple. I found this short code on a blog https://raw.githubusercontent.com/makermovement/3.5-Sensor2Phone/master/generate_any_audio.py [edit: the variable Fs might need to be changed to sampling_rate in the non-sine waves]

which can be tweaked fairly intuitively (er, for me, someone who has been playing music for over 20 years): change "samples" number for different length files, add more for loops for different sequences, use different functions for different waveforms.

Since the waveforms are generated by values in lists being packed into byte sequences, I imagine someone could use spike data (maybe transformed a bit to be in range [-128, 127]) instead of something that generates a sinewave or whatever.

My original idea was to have the spikes trigger a wav file to be played, to make a spiking drum machine, which seems possible with #pygame, #pyaudio, or a module called playsound, but I realized it would require stitching them together and also generating silence, so I went for the simpler method that's more like a synthesizer

title: Notes From Twitter Jail, Part II

last_post.content:

title: Column: Are you a victim of algorithmic wage discrimination? If not, just wait

last_post.content:
Ok let’s do this! For The Markup’s first #Newstodon Friday, we’re reading this piece which summarizes recent research into “algorithmic wage discrimination.” https://www.latimes.com/business/technology/story/2023-04-11/algorithmic-wage-discrimination

The finding is that gig companies are using algorithms to discover the lowest rate that people are willing to work for.

Tagging in our friends at @gbhnews @TexasObserver @damemagazine @STAT @mongabay @conversationus @thexylom and more to share a piece! #journalism #fediverse

Now that #NPR left #Twitter and many on #Mastodon are calling for it to come to the #Fediverse, maybe it's time for a recap, what we https://social.heise.de/@heiseonline did?

Our first account on mastodon.social was registered ("claimed") years ago, but left dormant until #ElonMusk bought #Twitter. Then I started to post a couple of links to #news articles every day. title: anthropocenemagazine.org/2022/...

last_post.content:
The Almond Pirates by @annaleen (published in Anthropocene Magazine) deserves awards.

On top of Newitz' always-excellent prose, it's a deeply human story about community and the distribution of resources.

Most of all, it's the best SFF about restorative and reparative justice you'll read.

If we (as progressive SFF fans) truly believe in dealing with systemic inequity in policing and justice, we need to be imagining this kind of system and depicting it with integrity.

https://www.anthropocenemagazine.org/2022/09/the-almond-pirates

title: GitHub - dokato/todor: TODOr - RStudio add-in for finding TODO, FIXME, CHANGED etc. comments in your code.

last_post.content:
TODOr is a sweet #RStats package that’s really handy for package developers.

If you write comments such as TODO, FIXME, IDEA etc as you’re working in an RStudio project, a call to `todor()` lists in a ‘Markers’ pane all the places they occur, and any further comment alongside them.

This makes it really easy to see what needs doing/fixing etc and to go back to those places.

The package also provides an RStudio Addin.

https://github.com/dokato/todor

title: OpenAI’s CEO confirms the company isn’t training GPT-5 and ‘won’t for some time’

last_post.content:
OpenAI confirms that it is not currently training GPT-5 and doesn't have plans to do so in the near future.

This is in line with my current belief that GPT-4 is pretty close to where LLMs will peak.

There are still a lot of other things that can be done that are more incremental changes, and more area to explore in the multimodal space. Plus work making smaller models that share similar capabilities to GPT-4. As the article says, version numbers can be misleading.

https://www.theverge.com/2023/4/14/23683084/openai-gpt-5-rumors-training-sam-altman

title: How to fine tune a 6B parameter LLM for less than $7

last_post.content:
A cost-effective method for fine-tuning and serving large language models (LLMs) using HuggingFace, DeepSpeed, and Ray, making it possible to serve a 6 billion parameter GPT-J model in just 40 minutes for under $7. This approach offers AI teams a faster, more affordable alternative to using a single large machine, enabling easier access to LLM capabilities.
#MachineLearning #LLM #LLMs #NLproc
https://www.anyscale.com/blog/how-to-fine-tune-and-serve-llms-simply-quickly-and-cost-effectively-using

title: The Console That Changed Mixing Forever

last_post.content: Completely engrossed by this documentary about the first computer-controlled audio mixing console, the Solid State Logic SL 4000 E.
